title: Quiz 10: Sociology in Nursing Practice
description: Apply your knowledge of sociology and anthropology to clinical nursing scenarios and professional development.

questions.question: Why is it important for nurses to study sociology and anthropology?

options.text: To learn how to perform surgery
To appreciate that individuals behave uniquely and tailor care accordingly
To treat all patients exactly the same way regardless of background
To avoid talking to patients' families

questions.explanation: Sociology helps nurses understand individual differences and social contexts, allowing for tailored care.

questions.question: The process by which a student nurse learns the ways of the profession, adapts to the hospital world, and becomes a recognised nurse is called ___BLANK___ socialisation.
questions.explanation: Professional socialisation is the adaptation to the specific culture of a profession.

questions.question: Which factors should a nurse assess regarding a patient's background to plan effective care? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Physical environment (housing, water)
Social background (family relationships)
Psychological factors (grief, stress)
None of the above

questions.explanation: Environment, social ties, and psychology all influence health and recovery.

questions.question: Observing a patient's style of dressing, language, and accompanying relatives provides valuable background information for the patient's history.
questions.explanation: Observation provides cues about cultural background and social support.

questions.question: Read the scenario: 'A Somali girl is brought to the ward by her parents. The nurse greets the parents in their language, offers chairs, and explains the procedure before starting.' What is the primary benefit of this approach?

richContent.content: Scenario: Culturally sensitive admission process.

options.text: It wastes time.
It makes the family feel accepted and welcomed, facilitating information sharing.
It ensures the nurse gets a tip.
It is required by law.

questions.explanation: Cultural sensitivity builds rapport and trust, making care delivery more effective.

questions.question: Match the sociological factor to its health impact:

pairs.right: Related to life expectancy and chronic disease prevalence
Provides buffer against stress and aids recovery
Influences symptom perception and health seeking behaviour

questions.explanation: Marital status affects longevity. Support aids coping. Culture affects how we see illness.
questions.hint: Marriage = Life expectancy; Support = Stress buffer.

questions.question: Nurses should ignore a patient's family and focus only on the individual patient to ensure privacy.
questions.explanation: Nurses should involve significant family members as individuals are part of a wider community that affects their health.
questions.hint: Is a patient isolated from their family?

questions.question: What is the rationale for community-based public health interventions?

options.text: It is cheaper than hospital care.
The role of cultural factors in determining health status.
Hospitals are full.
Doctors prefer it.

questions.explanation: Understanding that culture determines health status drives the need for community-based interventions.

questions.question: What term refers to the ability to cope with life changes and fit within society?
questions.explanation: Adaptation is the process of adjusting to new environments or changes.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the nurse's role in relation to sociology?

options.text: To change the patient's culture
To judge the patient's social status
To acknowledge social influences and interact professionally
To ignore social factors

questions.explanation: Nurses use sociological knowledge to interact professionally and understand patient contexts.
